nodes.name: Wage stagnation and declining labor share in advanced economies
nodes.description: Risk that average real wages plateau and the proportion of national income paid to workers falls as AI substitutes for labor.
nodes.node_rationale: Central risk repeatedly highlighted in Task-automation sections (§4.2).

nodes.name: High capital–labor substitutability via AI robotics in production
nodes.description: AI-enabled robots allow capital to be used interchangeably with labor, raising the substitution parameter towards or at unity.
nodes.node_rationale: Problem mechanism causing wage pressure – see “Perfect substitution” section (§3.3).

nodes.name: Task automation without proportionate task creation reduces labor demand
nodes.description: When the set of automatable tasks grows faster than new human-centric tasks appear, effective labor demand falls.
nodes.node_rationale: Theoretical channel in ‘Task creation’ (§4.2) explaining why high substitutability depresses wages.

nodes.name: Policy-led human-complementary task creation strategy
nodes.description: Design principle that governments should encourage emergence of new tasks that complement human capabilities, offsetting pure automation.
nodes.node_rationale: Proposed in §4.2 ‘Task creation’ as way to keep labor demand robust.

nodes.name: Government R&D incentives for novel human-centric sectors
aliases: innovation grants for labor complementary tech
nodes.description: Economic instruments such as targeted R&D tax credits and grants that steer innovation toward products and services requiring human strengths.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism by which task-creation strategy could be operationalised – implied in §4.2.

nodes.name: Historical task turnover maintaining labor share (Autor 2015 evidence)
nodes.description: Empirical finding that continual emergence of new occupations historically prevented large labour-share falls, supporting task-creation hypothesis.
nodes.node_rationale: Cited in ‘Task replacement’ (§4.4) as supporting evidence.

nodes.name: Implement task-creation incentive policies during AI deployment
nodes.description: During large-scale AI adoption, provide tax credits, prizes and regulatory support for industries that generate new human-complementary activities.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies when systems are moving into real-economy deployment – ‘Task automation’ section emphasises policy phase.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only model-based evidence exists; few scaled pilots – referencing §4.2.
nodes.node_rationale: Actionable step derived from design rationale to mitigate wage-share risk.

nodes.name: Technology growth slowdown and stagnation in AI-driven economy
nodes.description: Risk that aggregate productivity growth decelerates because firms under-invest in R&D when AI makes imitation easier.
nodes.node_rationale: Highlighted in ‘Growth impacts via impacts on technology investment’ (§5.4).

nodes.name: AI-enabled rapid imitation reducing R&D appropriability
nodes.description: Machine learning systems can decode and replicate new designs quickly, eroding patentees’ temporary monopoly rents.
nodes.node_rationale: Problem mechanism described in §5.4.

nodes.name: Reduced returns on innovation depress private R&D investment
nodes.description: Theoretical result that when appropriability falls, optimal firm R&D spending declines, lowering aggregate technology growth.
nodes.node_rationale: Derived in Aghion et al. model (§5.4).

nodes.name: Strengthen innovation incentives through public subsidies and IP reform
nodes.description: Design principle: compensate for imitation by increasing public funding of basic research and adapting patent law to the AI era.
nodes.node_rationale: Proposed fix in §5.4.

nodes.name: Public AI research funding and updated patent frameworks
nodes.description: Mechanisms: grants, matched funding, extended patent terms, or data-exclusive rights for AI-generated inventions.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanistic levers described in same §5.4 discussion.

nodes.name: Aghion 2019 model showing growth drop when IP weakened
nodes.description: Quantitative model where easier imitation cuts R&D rents, leading to lower steady-state innovation and GDP growth.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides empirical-style support (§5.4).

nodes.name: Establish AI-era innovation incentive mechanisms pre-deployment
nodes.description: Before widespread commercial AI rollout, enact subsidy programmes and IP reforms tailored to AI-enabled fast imitation.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Policies applied during deployment phase, per §5.4 recommendations.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Limited pilots; policy proposals under discussion – §5.4.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete policy action flowing from design rationale.

nodes.name: Runaway capital-driven growth exceeding environmental resource limits
nodes.description: Risk that recursive AI-driven capital accumulation pushes output beyond physical resource ceilings, causing instability.
nodes.node_rationale: Raised in ‘Automated research’ & land-constraint discussions (§3.3, §5.2).

nodes.name: Recursive self-improvement loop between AI-automated research and capital accumulation
aliases: positive feedback loop in AI R&D
nodes.description: Automated R&D accelerates technology, which raises capital productivity, funding still more R&D – a positive feedback.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism producing growth singularity – see §5.2.

nodes.name: Positive feedback in automated research can create Type I/II growth singularities
nodes.description: Models show that if research productivity exponent φ>0, output growth accelerates super-exponentially or diverges in finite time.
nodes.node_rationale: Key insight formally derived in ‘Automated research’ (§5.2).

nodes.name: Integrate resource constraints into AI economic planning to prevent overshoot
nodes.description: Design principle: explicitly model land, energy and environmental limits when planning AI-driven capital expansion.
nodes.node_rationale: Suggested solution in land-constraint subsections (§3.3).

nodes.name: Regulatory caps on AI-driven capital expansion tied to resource usage
nodes.description: Mechanism: impose permits, carbon/energy budgets or land-use quotas that scale inversely with measured resource depletion.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete lever aligning with design rationale – based on §3.3 discussion.

nodes.name: Models with land constraint show wages collapse when resource limited (Korinek & Stiglitz 2019)
nodes.description: Validation from models where fixed-supply resource causes labour share to drop to zero despite growth in capital.
nodes.node_rationale: Empirical-style support drawn from §3.3 models.

nodes.name: Institute sustainability-linked regulations on AI industrial scaling
nodes.description: Create legally binding sustainability metrics that gate AI-enabled capital deployment, preventing overshoot beyond physical limits.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies during deployment of large-scale AI-driven industries – §3.3.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Policy proposals exist; limited pilot schemes – §3.3.
nodes.node_rationale: Action directly stemming from design rationale.

nodes.name: Negative output growth from reduced saving after automation shock
nodes.description: Risk that output growth turns negative because automation lowers wages, reducing aggregate saving and investment.
nodes.node_rationale: Identified in ‘Growth impacts via impacts on saving’ (§3.4).

nodes.name: Income redistribution towards low-saving cohorts following wage decline
nodes.description: Automation transfers income from young wage-earners (higher saving) to retirees or rentiers with lower propensity to save.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism in Sachs & Kotlikoff OLG model (§3.4).

nodes.name: Saving rate decline depresses capital formation and future output
nodes.description: Theoretical result: lower aggregate saving reduces capital stock growth, leading to future output contraction.
nodes.node_rationale: Explicit conclusion in §3.4.

nodes.name: Maintain investment via redistribution or subsidies
nodes.description: Design principle: counter falling saving by redistributing income to high-saving groups or subsidising investment directly.
nodes.node_rationale: Proposed remedy in §3.4.

nodes.name: Progressive taxation and investment subsidies targeting workers
nodes.description: Mechanisms include higher capital-income taxes funding transfers to workers, and tax credits for pension or equipment investment.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanistic levers suggested in §3.4.

nodes.name: Sachs & Kotlikoff OLG model output drop evidence
nodes.description: Model shows that after a robot productivity shock, lower wages cut young workers’ saving, causing long-run output to fall.
nodes.node_rationale: Validation evidence from §3.4.

nodes.name: Apply fiscal redistribution policies during AI-driven automation transitions
nodes.description: Introduce progressive tax and targeted investment subsidies contemporaneously with automation waves to stabilise saving and growth.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Fiscal measures enacted during economic deployment phase – §3.4.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Policy debate stage; limited empirical trials – §3.4.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete intervention drawn from design rationale.
